record.title: Macquarie, Lachlan
record.detail: Governor of New South Wales from 1810 to 1821, Macquarie shaped Sydney's built environment, social structure, financial development and public morals.

record.title: Assassination attempt on Prince Alfred 1868
record.detail: In 1868, Henry O'Farrell tried to shoot the visiting Duke of Edinburgh, Prince Alfred, second son of Queen Victoria. Although the prince was only slightly wounded, the event set off a rash of anti-Irish feeling in Sydney, and O'Farrell was hanged in record time. Sydney's Royal Prince Alfred Hospital is a reminder of the event.

record.title: Australian Hall
record.detail: One of the few European buildings recognised as an Aboriginal heritage site, the Australian Hall was conserved because of its importance as the site for the 1938 Day of Mourning.

record.title: AWA Tower
record.detail: Topping the Art Deco AWA building, the tower was modelled on the Eiffel Tower in Paris, and once dominated Sydney's skyline.

record.title: Baha'i House of Worship
record.detail: Baha'i faith was brought to Australia in 1920 by Clara and Hyde Dunn. Sydney's Baha'i house of worship was designed by John Brogan and built on the highest point above the northern beaches of Sydney.
written by Garry Wotherspoon and Emma Grahame

record.title: Bank of New South Wales
record.detail: From the gold rush of the 1850s to the depression of the 1930s, Australia's oldest bank, now known as Westpac, has ridden the tide of the economy to serve Sydneysiders since the colony's infancy.

record.title: Barrenjoey lighthouse
record.detail: Designed by colonial architect James Barnet, the Barrenjoey lighthouse has lit up the entrance to Broken Bay for over 120 years.

record.title: Bats
record.detail: Sydney's evening skies contain flights of massed grey-headed flying foxes, the fruit bats that live in great numbers in the Royal Botanic Gardens, Gordon, Cabramatta and other pockets of bush across the city.

record.title: Bodegas
record.detail: Founded by the Spanish and Portuguese residents of Darlinghurst in the late nineteenth century, bodegas operated as wine bars throughout the twentieth century, coming into their own as postwar migrants looked for food and wine from home.

record.title: Bondi Pavilion
record.detail: Designed to hold 12,000 visitors, the Bondi Pavilion was part of an ambitious improvement scheme for Bondi Beach during the 1920s. Hugely popular and well used during the 1930s, the pavilion fell into decline by the 1960s and was only saved in the 1970s by the conversion of the ballroom into a theatre. Since then, the pavilion has found new functions and users.

record.title: Bradbury
record.detail: Dharawal country until the 1810s, when settlers and soldiers moved in, leading to armed conflict, the Bradbury area was subsequently named for William Bradbury, a settler and pub owner. Tanneries and a flour mill were built, amid the dairy farms that dominated the landscape. In the 1960s new suburbs were built as Sydney expanded.

record.title: Busby's Bore
record.detail: Part of the new water system designed by John Busby in the 1820s, Busby's Bore was a major piece of engineering infrastructure for the city, and supplied a population of 20,000 with 1.5 million litres of water per day.

record.title: Chifley Square
record.detail: Created by successive city councils through resumptions and rebuilding, Chifley Square was a venue for anti-conscription demonstrations during the Vietnam War.

record.title: Colonial Sugar Refining Co Ltd
record.detail: Founded in 1855, CSR had refineries in Canterbury, Chippendale, Pyrmont and later around Australia. It became a large and influential industrial company, with city offices and diversified business interests.

record.title: Commissariat Stores
record.detail: The Commissariat held a strategic role in the economy of the early colony, supplying and storing foodstuffs and other necessities – including liquor, hardware and other goods – for the population.

record.title: County of Cumberland Planning Scheme
record.detail: Based on an initiative of the Labor state government of William McKell in 1945, the Scheme was designed to coordinate planning and growth between metropolitan Sydney's many councils, and preserve the 'green belt' that would prevent urban sprawl.

record.title: Darlinghurst courthouse
record.detail: Darlinghurst Courthouse was an early purpose-built courthouse that inspired courthouse design throughout the colony for the rest of the nineteenth century. The building redefined the streetscape of Darlinghurst Hill, and played a large part in Sydney's legal history.

record.title: Darlinghurst Gaol
record.detail: Planned from the 1820s, Darlinghurst Gaol was built in stages to designs that shifted with penal theories and government budgets. From 1841 prisoners were kept there, in increasingly overcrowded and unpleasant conditions. After Long Bay prison was opened in 1914 the buildings were used for a range of other purposes.

record.title: Day of Mourning 1938
record.detail: Attended by Aboriginal activists from all over Australia, the Day of Mourning was the first national Aboriginal civil rights gathering.

record.title: Dunbar shipwreck
record.detail: In stormy weather, in the dark, after 81 days at sea, the Dunbar hit the rocks below The Gap, breaking up immediately. All but one on board were drowned, in one of the worst disasters in Sydney's history.

record.title: Endeavour
record.detail: Built as a collier, Captain James Cook's ship Endeavour carried him around the world and up the east coast of Australia in 1768-71, before becoming a coal ship again.

record.title: Felix the cat
record.detail: Possibly the first animated celebrity, drawn by Pat Sullivan, born Patrick O'Sullivan in Sydney.

record.title: Fishers Ghost Creek
record.detail: Murdered in 1826, Frederick Fisher is commemorated by Fisher's Ghost Creek, where legend has it that the ghost led the way to his own grave, thereby implicating his murderer, who was convicted and hanged.

record.title: Gilead
record.detail: Named after an 1812 land grant, Gilead was to grow from an important dairy farming area to one of the largest suburbs in the Campbelltown district.

record.title: Glenfield
record.detail: From a land grant to emancipist James Meehan, Glenfield was to become one of the fastest growing suburbs in the Campbelltown area.

record.title: Granville
record.detail: A significant meeting place for the Cadigal people, Granville's forests gave way to heavy industry and housing for workers as industrialists were attracted by its road, rail and water access.

record.title: Harbour pilots
record.detail: Though representing one of Sydney's least known professions, harbour pilots have kept Sydney Harbour and Botany Bay safe for commercial shipping from the earliest days of settlement.

record.title: Harris Park
record.detail: Originally home of the Barramattagal, the Toongagal and the Bidjigal people, Harris Park evolved as land was granted to colonists which was eventually broken up for residential subdivisions when a railway station was established in 1880.

record.title: Hornby lighthouse
record.detail: Constructed after two disastrous shipwrecks, Hornby lighthouse has offered safe passage into Sydney Harbour since 1858.

record.title: Hotel Australia
record.detail: An Art Deco fantasy of black marble and silver, the Australia Hotel was one of Sydney's most elegant until its demolition in the 1960s.

record.title: Japanese submarine attack 1942
record.detail: Often warned of the possibility of invasion, Sydneysiders were to experience the real thing in 1942 when three Japanese midget submarines slipped into the harbour, destroying the naval ship HMAS Kuttabul.

record.title: Kentlyn
record.detail: Part of the old Campbelltown common opened for selection in 1894, the area called Kent Farms was subdivided into 5-acre blocks in the 1920s and named Kentlyn in the 1930s. When neighbouring suburbs were densely developed after World War II, Kentlyn was still zoned for 5-acre blocks, and its bushland character remained.

record.title: Lighthouses
record.detail: Sydney's 14 lighthouses guide shipping through the Heads of the harbour, into Botany Bay, and into Broken Bay, as well as around the harbour.

record.title: Macquarie, Lachlan
record.detail: Governor of New South Wales from 1810 to 1821, Macquarie shaped Sydney's built environment, social structure, financial development and public morals.

record.title: Minto
record.detail: Built on the land granted to William Redfern by Governor Macquarie, Minto was a dairying and farming village for many decades, until post-World War II development began to encroach on Sydney's rural fringe. New suburban development in the 1980s led to an influx of young families, and Minto was transformed.

record.title: Minto Heights
record.detail: Minto Heights is a new suburb based on the old village of East Minto, which was based on small mixed and dairy farms in the nineteenth century, though most were gone by the 1950s. Zoned as regional open space, the area has not been densely developed, and has become an elite suburb in Campbelltown.

record.title: Paris Theatre
record.detail: The long and varied cultural history of the Paris Theatre, home to movies, vaudeville, cabaret, 'revues' and drama, gives an insight into the ups and downs of theatre and cinema life in Sydney over the twentieth century.

record.title: Rose Hill Packet
record.detail: Built in 1789 and quickly known as 'The Lump', the Rose Hill Packet was the first ship built in Sydney Cove, and transported convicts, passengers and freight along the Parramatta River to Rose Hill.

record.title: Rosehill
record.detail: Where the Parramatta and Duck rivers meet was also a meeting place for the Cadigal and the Wategora, Barramattagal and Bidjigal clans of the Dharug, before Europeans arrived and took the land. John Macarthur established Elizabeth Farm which remained intact until it was subdivided as Rosehill in 1880. The railway and river frontage made the area attractive for industry, some of which remains.

record.title: Rowe Street
record.detail: A narrow laneway, running between Pitt and Castlereagh streets, Rowe Street was small-scale, personable, cosmopolitan, and fun.

record.title: Royal Botanic Gardens
record.detail: Planted on land set aside for the governor's demesne, the Botanic Gardens began as kitchen gardens but by the 1840s were already filled with many native and exotic trees and plants for propagation, study and experiment. from the 1850s, the Gardens were laid out according to Victorian principles of garden design, with elements that still give the place a Victorian air.

record.title: Rydalmere
record.detail: Originally Burramattagal country, the area that became Rydalmere was granted to Philip Schaeffer, who planted vines, and the land was later acquired by Hannibal Macarthur who built a grand house, later a Catholic girls' school. The area was named Rydalmere in 1886 when it was subdivided, but remained semi-rural, with orchards and poultry farms until industry moved in from the 1940s.

record.title: Simmos Beach
record.detail: Badly affected by sandmining during the 1950s and 1960s, this Georges River beach was rehabilitated by the council in the 1970s and a public reserve created.

record.title: Sydney Mechanics' School of Arts
record.detail: Founded in 1833 on the model of Scottish Mechanics' Institutes, the SMSA sought to provide further education for working men through lectures, classes and a library. Many of Sydney's foremost intellectuals, inventors and innovators were associated with it, and it influenced the development of both the University of Sydney and technical education in New South Wales. It still provides a library and lectures to Sydneysiders in 2009.

record.title: Sydney punchbowl
record.detail: Painted in the 1810s, from a drawing by John Lewin, the Sydney punchbowl, and others like it, recorded the appearance of the new colony in a durable way.

record.title: Sydney rock oysters
record.detail: Gathered by Aboriginal people for thousands of years before the Europeans arrived, Sydney oysters became a farmed product in the 1870s and remain a popular seafood.

record.title: Sydney to Hobart yacht race
record.detail: Held every year since 1945, the Sydney to Hobart yacht race is one of the highlights of Sydney sailing, and one of the great races in the world.

record.title: Trocadero
record.detail: Once the most glamorous dance hall in Sydney, the Trocadero hosted Queens, Dukes, and international stars, as well as Sydneysiders out for a good time.

record.title: Varroville
record.detail: Named for Varro Ville, the country estate of Robert Townson, Varroville remained a rural retreat well into the twentieth century, with dairy farming the main economic activity.

record.title: Victa Mowers Pty Ltd
record.detail: Invented in Sydney, and adapted by the founder of Victa, the rotary lawnmower made a neat lawn easy to maintain, just in time for Sydney's postwar suburban expansion.

record.title: Windmills
record.detail: From 1797 when the first windmill started grinding the colony's grain, windmills were distinctive landmarks in Sydney, standing along the ridge lines around the harbour. Streets named Windmill in different parts of the city are remnants of this lost technology.

record.title: Wylie's Baths
record.detail: Ocean baths were established south of Coogee beach in 1907 by Henry Wylie, father of Australia's first champion woman swimmer, Mina Wylie. They have been inspirational to swimmers, painters and filmmakers, and are still open.

record.title: Macquarie, Lachlan
record.detail: Governor of New South Wales from 1810 to 1821, Macquarie shaped Sydney's built environment, social structure, financial development and public morals.

record.title: Bligh, William (Person)
record.detail: Governor of New South Wales who was overthrown in the Rum Rebellion of 1808.

record.title: Hyde Park Barracks (Place)
record.detail: Sydney landmark designed by Francis Greenway to house male convicts, which subsequently became an immigration depot, government asylum, law courts and museum.

record.title: Macquarie, Lachlan
record.detail: Governor of New South Wales from 1810 to 1821, Macquarie shaped Sydney's built environment, social structure, financial development and public morals.

record.title: Greenway, Francis (Person)
record.detail: English-born architect transported to Australia for forgery who became an iconic colonial architect under the patronage of Governor Lachlan Macquarie.

record.title: Macquarie, Lachlan
record.detail: Governor of New South Wales from 1810 to 1821, Macquarie shaped Sydney's built environment, social structure, financial development and public morals.

record.title: Phillip, Arthur (Person)
record.detail: British naval officer who became first Governor of New South Wales, leading the colony for five difficult years.

record.title: Macquarie, Lachlan
record.detail: Governor of New South Wales from 1810 to 1821, Macquarie shaped Sydney's built environment, social structure, financial development and public morals.

record.title: Few
Lachlan Macquarie c1810
record.detail: The male in this portrait wears a dress uniform that comprises a military jacket of red face cloth and a blue-black stand collar, gold epaulettes, and regimental brass buttons.

record.title: Macquarie, Lachlan
record.detail: Governor of New South Wales from 1810 to 1821, Macquarie shaped Sydney's built environment, social structure, financial development and public morals.

Lachlan Macquarie was the first governor who was not a naval officer. His focus was turned landwards, where he aimed to enhance his reputation through creating orderly urban spaces and commissioning the construction of fine buildings.
IMG SLNSW a128641 Lachlan Macquarie, ca. 1810 - watercolour on ivory miniature

record.title: Macquarie
Macquarie, Lachlan
record.detail: Governor of New South Wales from 1810 to 1821, Macquarie shaped Sydney's built environment, social structure, financial development and public morals.

record.detail: Lachlan Macquarie's Commission as Governor of New South Wales 8 May 1809

A true copy, sealed by Thomas Campbell, of Macquarie's commission appointing him Captain-General and Governor-in-Chief over the Territory of New South Wales.

record.title: Part
Macquarie, Lachlan
record.detail: Governor of New South Wales from 1810 to 1821, Macquarie shaped Sydney's built environment, social structure, financial development and public morals.

Hyde Park Barracks, designed by Francis Greenway, have been used to house convicts, Irish orphans and law courts. In the 1960s there were voices calling for demolition. Today they are one of Sydney's most loved buildings from the Macquarie era.
IMG Hyde Park Barracks, Sydney c1840-1850

record.title: Macquarie
Simeon Lord c1830
record.detail: Simeon Lord, c. 1830 - watercolour on ivory miniature. Simeon Lord, entrepreneur and pastoralist, was transported to Sydney from England in 1791. Emancipated early, Lord initially traded and imported cargo. Lord expanded his mercantile holdings and wealth by exporting oil and sealskins to England. He acquired large land grants that included the Dobroyd estate, Ashfield, Sydney. -- Reference: Australian Dictionary of Biography. Vol.6, 1851-1890. Carlton, Vic.: Melbourne University Press, 1976

record.title: Macquarie, Lachlan
record.detail: Governor of New South Wales from 1810 to 1821, Macquarie shaped Sydney's built environment, social structure, financial development and public morals.

Simeon Lord appears here a picture of respectability, despite having arrived as a convict in 1791. He eventually became one of the wealthiest men in Sydney and Macquarie appointed him as a magistrate in 1810.
IMG SLNSW a128827 Simeon Lord, c. 1830 - watercolour on ivory miniature

record.title: Macquarie
Macquarie, Lachlan
record.detail: Governor of New South Wales from 1810 to 1821, Macquarie shaped Sydney's built environment, social structure, financial development and public morals.

record.title: 'One of the NSW Aborigines befriended by Governor Macquarie' c1810-1821
record.detail: 'One of the NSW Aborigines befriended by Governor Macquarie' c1810-1821

One of the NSW Aborigines befriended by Governor Macquarie. ""Painting was for years in the possession of Gov. Macquarie. It belonged to Mrs Agnes Flockhart, youngest daughter of Robert Porter, who was for 20 years in the service of Gen. Lachlan Macquarie and his widow as manager for their estate at Glen Forsa, Scotland"" -- handwritten in pencil on reverse
This undated and unsigned portrait was probably painted for the Macquaries, and it remained in their possession for many years after they returned from Sydney to Scotland.
IMG SLNSW a128458 One of the NSW Aborigines befriended by Governor Macquarie

Holey dollar, silver 1813

record.title: Macquarie, Lachlan
record.detail: Governor of New South Wales from 1810 to 1821, Macquarie shaped Sydney's built environment, social structure, financial development and public morals.

Macquarie's purchase of Spanish dollars in 1813 doubled the amount of currency in circulation. The face value of the dollar was five shillings, but with an additional value of one shilling and threepence placed on the dump, the total value of the currency also rose.

record.title: Macquarie
Proclamation by Governor Lachlan Macquarie, 3 March 1810
record.detail: Proclamation by Governor Lachlan Macquarie, 3 March 1810

record.title: Macquarie, Lachlan
record.detail: Governor of New South Wales from 1810 to 1821, Macquarie shaped Sydney's built environment, social structure, financial development and public morals.
Macquarie the moralist is here recording his disgust at scandalous cohabitation out of wedlock and vowing to crack down on houses of ill repute.

record.detail: Governor of New South Wales from 1810 to 1821, Macquarie shaped Sydney's built environment, social structure, financial development and public morals.

record.title: Macquarie, Lachlan (Person)
record.detail: British military officer who became the fifth Governor of New South Wales and was responsible for extensive social, economic and architectural development in the colony.

record.title: Macquarie, Lachlan (Person)
record.detail: British military officer who became the fifth Governor of New South Wales and was responsible for extensive social, economic and architectural development in the colony.

record.title: Lachlan Macquarie, early 1800s
record.detail:
P-ID: 929 P-DoS Notes: CAPTION ALREADY WRITTEN: Though generally considered to be a painting of Lachlan Macquarie, the attribution and date of this portrait remain unclear, and the military uniform does not accord with Macquarie's rank or regiment. It may be Lachlan's brother, Charles.
Donor believed the artist to be John Graham (later known as John Graham- Gilbert). Later the Mitchell Library attributed the painting to John Opie, as there is a reference to Macquarie sitting for Opie in Macquarie's journal, dated 20 April 1805 (A770, p.576). In April 1987, the portrait was unframed for cleaning. A signature "J Graham Gilbert RSA" inscribed in ink was noted on the lowest stetcher bar While attribution and creation date remain unclear, a further complication is that the military uniform of the subject does not accord with Macquarie's rank/regiment, casting doubt on whether the subject even is Lachlan Macquarie. It is possibly Lachlan's brother Charles. P-Related: Topic - Governance

record.title: Macquarie, Lachlan, Relationship, Spouse
record.detail: Jane Jarvis was a West Indian heiress and youngest daughter of the late Thomas Jarvis, former chief justice of Antigua. They were married in Bombay (Mumbai) but she died in July, 1796.

record.title: Lachlan Macquarie, early 1800s
record.detail:
P-ID: 929 P-DoS Notes: CAPTION ALREADY WRITTEN: Though generally considered to be a painting of Lachlan Macquarie, the attribution and date of this portrait remain unclear, and the military uniform does not accord with Macquarie's rank or regiment. It may be Lachlan's brother, Charles.
Donor believed the artist to be John Graham (later known as John Graham- Gilbert). Later the Mitchell Library attributed the painting to John Opie, as there is a reference to Macquarie sitting for Opie in Macquarie's journal, dated 20 April 1805 (A770, p.576). In April 1987, the portrait was unframed for cleaning. A signature "J Graham Gilbert RSA" inscribed in ink was noted on the lowest stetcher bar While attribution and creation date remain unclear, a further complication is that the military uniform of the subject does not accord with Macquarie's rank/regiment, casting doubt on whether the subject even is Lachlan Macquarie. It is possibly Lachlan's brother Charles. P-Related: Topic - Governance
